channel.title: Posts on The Biology Reproducibility Project
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on The Biology Reproducibility Project

item.title: Data from: Response of bluebunch wheatgrass to invasion differences in competitive ability among invader-experienced and naïve populations
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Setup Import Reproducibility Table 1 Methods Check on balance The model is unclear Table 1–published Table 1 - repro Figure 1 Fig 1 – published Fig 1 – repro 3.1.1 Seedling 3.1.2 Juvenile 3.2 Relative Interaction Index Supression Fig 2 Fig 2 – published Fig 2 repro Statistical red flags Sources Gibson A, Nelson CR, Atwater DZ (2018) Response of bluebunch wheatgrass to invasion: Differences in competitive ability among invader-experienced and invader-naïve populations.

item.title: Data from: Herbivory and eutrophication mediate grassland plant nutrient responses across a global climatic gradient
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Setup Import Reproducibility Statistical red flags Sources Anderson TM, Griffith DM, Grace JB, Lind EM, Adler PB, Biederman LA, Blumenthal DM, Daleo P, Firn J, Hagenah N, Harpole WS, MacDougall AS, McCulley RL, Prober SM, Risch AC, Sankaran M, Schütz M, Seabloom EW, Stevens CJ, Sullivan LL, Wragg PD, Borer ET (2018) Herbivory and eutrophication mediate grassland plant nutrient responses across a global climatic gradient.

item.title: Data from: Perceived threats of infanticide reduce maternal allocation during lactation and lead to elevated oxidative damage in offspring
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Setup Import Reproducibility Offspring weight Maternal behaviour Glucocorticoid metabolites in mothers Fig. 3 Oxidative stress in offspring Statistical Red Flags 1. Computation of ANOVA table using Afex package How balanced is the design ANOVA using Afex (computation above) 3 ANOVA table using lme/lmer Compare LMM to ANOVA table using lm() and AOV (ignoring clustering due to repeated measures) Plot it to visualize the effects Sources Gale T, Garratt M, Brooks RC (2018) Perceived threats of infanticide reduce maternal allocation during lactation and lead to elevated oxidative damage in offspring.

item.title: Data from: Habitat management alters thermal opportunity
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Setup Import Cleaning Reproducibility Selected temperatures and thermal quality of habitat Thermal preference (Tset) Thermal quality of habitat (de) Table 1 Encounter rates Fig 2 Lizard body temperatures and extent of thermoregulation Thermal performance curves and critical thermal limits Statistical Red Flags Best practice recommendations Sources Neel LK, McBrayer LD (2018) Habitat management alters thermal opportunity. Functional Ecology 32(8): 2029-2039. https://doi.org/10.1111/1365-2435.13123

item.title: Data from: The significance of prey avoidance behaviour for the maintenance of a predator colour polymorphism

item.title: Data from Organic matter and nutrient inputs from large wildlife influence ecosystem function in the Mara River, Africa
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Set up Import Reproducibility Nutrient dissolution rates Statistical methods ANOVA results Posthoc pairwise comparisons Decomposition rates Statistical methods ANOVA results Nutrient limitation Statistical method Respiration Results Chlorophyll a results Ecosystem Function Experimental Streams River Biofilms Statistical red-flags Sources Subalusky AL, Dutton CL, Njoroge L, Rosi EJ, Post DM (2018) Organic matter and nutrient inputs from large wildlife influence ecosystem function in the Mara River, Africa.

item.title: Data from: Density-dependent positive feedbacks buffer aquatic plants from interactive effects of eutrophication and predator loss
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Set up Import data cleaning Reproducibility Appendix S5 Table S1 reproducing epiphytic algae biomass columns in-text Appendix S5 Table S2 Figure 2 Statistical Red-flags Figure red-flags Simulate this Sources Source: Donadi S, Austin ÅN, Svartgren E, Eriksson BK, Hansen JP, Eklöf JS (2018) Density-dependent positive feedbacks buffer aquatic plants from interactive effects of eutrophication and predator loss. Ecology 99(11): 2515-2524.

item.title: Data from: Litter removal in a tropical rain forest reduces fine root biomass and production but litter addition has few effects
item.description: Sources Summary Caveats Set up Functions import Note in file Data inconsistencies Data pre-processing Reproducibility Section: Fine root mass and production My ANOVA results reported ANOVA results Did the authors use a one way ANOVA with no random effects? Figure 1 post-hoc tests for fig 1 Fine root mass production effects of treatment on FRB and FRB production figure 2 Section: Fine root length: standing crop, production and survivorship table 1 Figure 3 post hoc tests for fig.

item.title: Data from: Interactions among predators and plant specificity protects herbivores from top predators
item.description: Summary Caveats Set up Import Reproducibility Effect on total predators my results reported results Effect on total herbaceous my results reported results ANOVA table in Appendix 3, Table S1 Fig 1 Subsetting the response spiders predatory insects Hemiptera Coleoptera Lepidoptera Orthoptera Fig S6 Statistical red-flags Source: Bosc C, Roets F, Hui C, Pauw A (2018) Interactions among predators and plant specificity protect herbivores from top predators.

item.title: Data from: Frequency of virus-resistant hosts determines experimental community dynamics
item.description: Summary Caveats Set up Reproducibility missing data Table 1 what model? AOV vs. lmer AOV computation Table 1 – my results Table 1 – reported results Did the authors throw out A3 for Chlorella and Rotifer? Table 2 AOV v lmer Table 2 – my results Table 2 – reported Did the authors throw out A3 for Chlorella and Rotifer? Figure 2 Statistical presentation Source: Coloma S, Gaedke U, Sivonen K, Hiltunen T (2018) Frequency of virus-resistant hosts determines experimental community dynamics.

item.title: Data from Critical thermal limits affected differently by developmental and adult thermal fluctuations

Journal of Experimental Biology 220(23): 4471-4478. https://doi.org/10.1242/jeb.165308 Salachan PV, Sørensen JG (2017) Data from: Critical thermal limits affected differently by developmental and adult thermal fluctuations.

item.title: Data from The interaction between predation risk and food ration on behavior and morphology of Eurasian perch
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Reproducibility Figure 1/Table 1 (Condition and Length) Condition index Table 1 Tukey Contrasts Figure 2/Table 2 (Behavior) Table 2 Morphometrics Post-publication review Sources Svanbäck R, Zha Y, Brönmark C, Johansson F (2017) The interaction between predation risk and food ration on behavior and morphology of Eurasian perch. Ecology and Evolution 7(20): 8567-8577. https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.3330 Svanback R, Zha Y, Brönmark C, Johansson F (2017) Data from: The interaction between predation risk and food ration on behavior and morphology of Eurasian perch.

item.title: Data from Ontogenetic thermal tolerance and performance of ectotherms at variable temperatures
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Summary of Re-analysis Reproducibility Post-publication review Reproducibility Table 1 Table 2 Table 3 Figure 2 Post-publication review Use the full model to compare to Huey & Kinsolver Table of contrasts needed for interpretation Harrell Plots of full model ignoring sex Summary of my Harrell Plots and Table of contrasts Shift in UTL Red Flags Statistical misconceptions Sources Cavieres G, Bogdanovich JM, Bozinovic F (2016) Ontogenetic thermal tolerance and performance of ectotherms at variable temperatures.

item.title: Data from: Success despite the stress -- violet-green swallows increase glucocorticoids and maintain reproductive output despite experimental increases in flight costs
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Data Reproducibility Initial measures Change in Cort Change in Body Mass Post-publication review “no significant differences” among treatment groups at baseline does not protect in any way against the bias in change scores (post - pre treatment measure) Estimates of treatment effects on Cortisol and Mass were not adjusted for baseline values Simulation to explore behavior in lmm vs. ANCOVA-lm vs. cLDA Adjustment for baseline comparing \(Cort_b\) Sources Rivers JW, Newberry GN, Schwarz CJ, Ardia DR (2017) Success despite the stress: violet-green swallows increase glucocorticoids and maintain reproductive output despite experimental increases in flight costs.

item.title: Data from: Density triggers maternal hormones that increase adaptive offspring growth in a wild mammal
item.description: Sources Background Reproducibility key Caveats Reproducibility Effect of spruce cone availability on local density (Fig. 1B) Effect of Density on growth rate (Fig. 2/Table S2) Effect of Density on fecal cortisol metabolites (Fig. 3/Table S4) Effect of FCM on offspring growth rate (Table S5) Effect of experiment Cortisol on growth rate (Table S6) Red flags Effect of Density on growth rate (Fig. 2/Table S2) Growth rate is a change score and is confounded by the basline Figure 2 doesn’t make sense Effect of Density on fecal cortisol metabolites (Fig.
